A single person can live comfortably on $800–$1,200 per month in Buenos Aires. Smaller cities drop that to $600–$900."}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"The key is understanding the dual currency economy. Official exchange rates differ from the informal \"blue dollar\" rate by 20–50%. Using services like Western Union or crypto exchanges that give you the blue rate effectively increases your purchasing power significantly."}]]}],["$","section",null,{"id":"monthly-budgets","className":"mb-12","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-2xl md:text-3xl font-bold mb-6","children":"Monthly Budgets by City"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-6","children":"These figures represent total monthly expenses for one person living moderately: private apartment, eating out a few times per week, occasional entertainment. Couples can expect roughly 1.6x these amounts (shared rent, split utilities)."}],["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-card border rounded-lg p-4 md:p-6 mb-6","children":["$","$L16",null,{"caption":"Monthly Costs by City (USD)","columns":[{"key":"city","header":"City"},{"key":"budget","header":"Monthly Budget","align":"right"},{"key":"rent1br","header":"1BR Rent","align":"right"},{"key":"rent3br","header":"3BR Rent","align":"right"}],"data":[{"city":"Buenos Aires","budget":"$$800 – $1,200","rent1br":"$$400 – $600","rent3br":"$$700 – $1,100","mealOut":"$$8 – $15","transport":"$$15 – $25"},{"city":"Mendoza","budget":"$$700 – $1,000","rent1br":"$$300 – $450","rent3br":"$$550 – $850","mealOut":"$$7 – $12","transport":"$$10 – $20"},{"city":"Cordoba","budget":"$$650 – $950","rent1br":"$$280 – $400","rent3br":"$$500 – $750","mealOut":"$$6 – $10","transport":"$$12 – $20"},{"city":"Bariloche","budget":"$$750 – $1,100","rent1br":"$$350 – $500","rent3br":"$$600 – $900","mealOut":"$$8 – $14","transport":"$$15 – $25"}]}]}],"$L17"]}],"$L18","$L19","$L1a","$L1b","$L1c","$L1d","$L1e"]}]]}]}]}]]}],["$L1f"],"$L20"]}]

18:["$","section",null,{"id":"housing","className":"mb-12","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-2xl md:text-3xl font-bold mb-4","children":"Housing Costs"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Rent takes the biggest bite from most budgets. In Buenos Aires, prices vary dramatically by neighborhood. Palermo and Recoleta command premium rents. San Telmo, Almagro, and Caballito offer better value."}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Most rentals require a garantía—a local property owner who guarantees your rent. This is nearly impossible for foreigners to obtain. Solutions include:"}],["$","ul",null,{"className":"list-disc pl-6 space-y-2 text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":[["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Airbnb monthly:"}]," More expensive but no garantía needed. Negotiate for 30%+ discounts on 3+ month stays."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Guarantor services:"}]," Companies like"," ",["$","em",null,{"children":" garantía BA"}]," charge 3–5% of annual rent to act as your guarantor."]}],["$","li",null,{"children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Foreigner-friendly landlords:"}]," Some accept larger security deposits (3–6 months) instead of garantía."]}]]}]]}]
19:["$","section",null,{"id":"food","className":"mb-12","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-2xl md:text-3xl font-bold mb-4","children":"Food & Dining"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Argentina food scene is a highlight for many expats. Steak dinners at traditional parrillas run $15–$25 with wine. A cafeteria-style lunch (menú del día) costs $4–$6."}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Cooking at home keeps costs down. Large supermarkets like Carrefour and Coto are affordable. Neighborhood verdulerías (produce shops) offer fresher vegetables at lower prices than chains."}]]}]
1a:["$","section",null,{"id":"transport","className":"mb-12","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-2xl md:text-3xl font-bold mb-4","children":"Transportation"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Buenos Aires has excellent and affordable public transit. The SUBE card works on buses, subways, and commuter trains. A single ride costs about $0.20–$0.30. Monthly passes make sense if you commute daily."}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Taxis and Uber are widely available. A 15-minute Uber ride typically costs $3–$5. Avoid taxis from the airport—book a remis (private car) in advance for fixed rates around $25–$35 to the city center."}]]}]
1b:["$","section",null,{"id":"utilities","className":"mb-12","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-2xl md:text-3xl font-bold mb-4","children":"Utilities & Services"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Electricity and gas bills have risen substantially as government subsidies decreased. A typical 1BR apartment now pays $40–$80 monthly for utilities, depending on usage and season."}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Internet is affordable and generally reliable in cities. Fiber plans with 100+ Mbps run $15–$25 per month. Mobile data is inexpensive by international standards—$5–$10 gets you several gigabytes."}]]}]
1c:["$","section",null,{"id":"healthcare","className":"mb-12","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-2xl md:text-3xl font-bold mb-4","children":"Healthcare Costs"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Argentina has a three-tier healthcare system. Public hospitals are free for everyone, including foreigners, though wait times can be long and facilities vary."}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Most expats opt for private prepaid medicine (prepaga) plans. Major providers like OSDE and Swiss Medical offer comprehensive coverage for $100–$300 per month depending on age and plan level. These plans include access to private hospitals, specialists without referrals, and often dental coverage."}]]}]
1d:["$","section",null,{"id":"visa-requirements","className":"mb-12","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-2xl md:text-3xl font-bold mb-4","children":"Visa Financial Requirements"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Argentina visa applications typically require proof of sufficient funds. For the digital nomad visa, you will need to show monthly income of approximately $1,500–$2,000 from a foreign source."}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"The rentista visa (passive income) requires proof of stable monthly income around $1,500 from investments, pensions, or rental properties. Specific amounts vary by consulate and are subject to change with inflation."}]]}]
